sen.j: 今宮神社（いまみやじんじゃ）は、京都市北区 (京都市)紫野にある神社である。
sen.e: "Imamiya-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Murasakino, Kita Ward, Kyoto City.
"Imamiya-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Murasakino, Kita Ward, Kyoto City.
"Imamiya-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Murasakino, Kita Ward, Kyoto City.
Its shrine ranking is the former prefectural shrine.
Its shrine ranking is former prefectural shrine.
Its shrine ranking is former prefectural shrine.

sen.cmt: 複数あるためdeitiesとしました。

sen.j: 現在の今宮神社は、994年（正暦5年）船岡山で御霊会が行われた後、1001年（長保3年）5月に現在の場所に神殿が造営されて3柱の神が祀られたのに始まるとされるが、現在の場所には創建年代については不明であるが、古くから疫病の神とされるスサノオを祀る社（現在摂社疫神社）があったという。
sen.e: The current Imamiya-jinja Shrine is said to have originated in May 1001 when the temple was built in the current location and the three gods were enshrined after Goryo-e was performed in Funaokayama in 994, but the year of establishment at the current location is unknown, although it has long been a shrine enshrining Susanoo (currently, sessha (auxiliary shrine (dedicated to a deity close-related to that of a main shrine)) Eki-jinjya Shrine), the god of epidemics.

The current Imamiya-jinja Shrine is said to have originated in May 1001 when the temple was built in the current location and the three gods were enshrined after Goryo-e was performed in Funaokayama in 994, but the year of establishment at the current location is unknown, although it has long been a shrine enshrining Susanoo (currently, sessha (auxiliary shrine - dedicated to a deity close-related to that of a main shrine) Eki-jinjya Shrine), the god of epidemics.

The current Imamiya-jinja Shrine is said to have originated in May 1001 when the temple was built in the current location and the three gods were enshrined after Goryo-e (ritual ceremony to repose of spirits of a deceased person) was performed in Mt. Funaoka in 994, but the year of establishment at the current location is unknown, although it has long been a shrine enshrining Susanoo (currently, sessha (auxiliary shrine - dedicated to a deity close-related to that of a main shrine) Eki-jinja Shrine), the god of epidemics.
sen.cmt: 御霊会の補足を入れました。船岡山は山の名称であるため、Mt. Funaokaとしました。Eki-jinjya Shrine→Eki-jinja Shrineに修正しました。

sen.j: 御霊会は今宮祭とも呼ばれ、平安時代末から鎌倉時代初期にかけて禁止された時期もあった。
sen.e: Goryo-e is also called Imamiya-sai Festival, and was prohibited for a while from the end of Heian period to the beginning of Kamakura period.
Goryo-e is also called Imamiya-sai Festival, and was prohibited for a while from the end of Heian period to the beginning of Kamakura period.
Goryo-e is also called Imamiya-sai Festival, and was prohibited for a while from the end of Heian period to the beginning of Kamakura period.

sen.j: 1284年（弘安7年）には正一位の神階が与えられ、江戸時代には社領として50石が与えられた。
sen.e: It was granted the shinkai (ranks granted to Shinto gods), Shoichii (Senior First Rank), in 1284, and was given a sharyo of 50 koku in the Edo period.
It was granted the shinkai (ranks granted to Shinto gods), Shoichii (Senior First Rank), in 1284, and was given a sharyo of 50 koku in the Edo period.
It was granted the shinkai (ranks granted to Shinto gods), Shoichii (Senior First Rank), in 1284, and was given a sharyo (territory of a shrine) of 50 koku in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 社領の補足を入れました。

sen.j: 無形民俗文化財（国指定）
sen.e: Intangible folk cultural property (designated by Japan)
Intangible folk cultural property (designated by Japan)
Intangible folk cultural property (designated by Japan)

sen.j: 京都府京都市北区紫野今宮町21
sen.e: 21 Imamiya-cho, Murasakino, Kita Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture
